bsb_verse_text: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, To the saints in Ephesus, the faithful in Christ Jesus:
ult_verse_text: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus through the will of God, to the saints, the ones being [in Ephesus]\f + \ft Many early versions do not include\fqa in Ephesus.\fqa*\f*

notes.note: Paul names himself as the writer of this letter to the believers in the church at Ephesus (and elsewhere). Except where noted, all instances of “you” and “your” refer to the Ephesian believers as well as to all believers, and so are plural.

notes.orig_language_quote: Παῦλος, ἀπόστολος Χριστοῦ Ἰησοῦ & τοῖς ἁγίοις τοῖς οὖσιν
notes.note: Your language may have a particular way of introducing the author of a letter and the intended audience. Alternate translation: [I, Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ … write this letter to you, God’s holy people]

The phrase **in Christ Jesus** and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him, picturing believers as being surrounded by Christ. Alternate translation: [in close relationship to Christ Jesus]

bsb_verse_text: Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
ult_verse_text: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

notes.note: This is a common greeting and blessing that Paul often uses in the beginning of his letters. Use a form in your language that makes it clear that this is a greeting and blessing.

bsb_verse_text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us in Christ with every spiritual blessing in the heavenly realms.
ult_verse_text: Blessed {be} the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the one having blessed us with every spiritual blessing in the heavenly {places} in Christ,

notes.note: In this book, unless otherwise stated, the words “us” and “we” refer to Paul, the believers in Ephesus, and all believers.

This verse provides background information about the Ephesians to help readers understand their spiritual condition. Paul opens his letter by talking about the believers’ position and their safety before God.

notes.orig_language_quote: εὐλογητὸς ὁ Θεὸς καὶ Πατὴρ τοῦ Κυρίου ἡμῶν, Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [Let us praise the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ]
Alternate translation: [for God has blessed us]
Alternate translation: [every blessing coming from the Spirit of God]

Paul assumes that his readers will understand that the word **heavenly** refers to the place where God is. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [in the supernatural world]

Here, **in Christ** could mean: (1) a metaphor referring to our close relationship with Christ. Alternate translation: [by uniting us with Christ] or [because we are united with Christ]; (2) what Christ has done. Alternate translation: [through Christ] or [through what Christ has done]

bsb_verse_text: For He chose us in Him before the foundation of the world to be holy and blameless in His presence. In love
ult_verse_text: just as he chose us in him from the foundation of the world, {for} us to be holy and blameless before him. In love

notes.note: Paul uses the two similar words **holy** and **blameless** to emphasize moral goodness. If your language does not have two similar words, you can use one word for both, as in the UST.

The word **blameless** contains two negative ideas: “blame” or “fault,” and “-less,” which means “without.” If it would be helpful in your language, the two negative ideas can be replaced with the corresponding positive idea, “perfect.”

bsb_verse_text: He predestined us for adoption as His sons through Jesus Christ, according to the good pleasure of His will,
ult_verse_text: he predestined us for adoption through Jesus Christ to himself, according to the good pleasure of his will,

notes.note: The words “he,” “himself,” and “his” refer to God.
The word **us** refers to Paul, the Ephesian church, and all believers in Christ. Alternate translation: [God planned long ago to adopt us]
Alternate translation: [God chose us ahead of time] or [God chose us long ago]
Here, **adoption** is a metaphor that refers to becoming part of God’s family. Alternate translation: [to become his children]
Paul assumes that his readers will understand that God brought believers into his family by the work of **Jesus Christ**. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers.

bsb_verse_text: to the praise of His glorious grace, which He has freely given us in the Beloved One.
ult_verse_text: to the praise of the glory of his grace that he has freely given us in the Beloved One,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [he has kindly given to us by means of the One whom he loves]
Alternate translation: [the One he loves, Jesus Christ] or [his Son, whom he loves]

bsb_verse_text: In Him we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of His grace
ult_verse_text: in whom we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of the trespasses, according to the riches of his grace,

notes.note: The **blood** of Jesus is a metonym for his death. Alternate translation: [because he died]
Paul speaks of God’s **grace** as if it were material wealth. Alternate translation: [greatness of God’s grace] or [abundance of God’s grace]

bsb_verse_text: that He lavished on us with all wisdom and understanding.
ult_verse_text: which he caused to abound to us in all wisdom and understanding.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [which he gave us in a great amount] or [being extremely kind to us]
This could mean: (1) because he has all wisdom and understanding. (2) so that we might have great wisdom and understanding.
Here, **wisdom** and **understanding** mean very similar things. If your language does not have two similar words, you can use one word for both.

bsb_verse_text: And He has made known to us the mystery of His will according to His good pleasure, which He purposed in Christ
ult_verse_text: He made known to us the mystery of his will according to his good pleasure, which he had planned in him,

notes.note: This could mean: (1) because he wanted to make it known to us. (2) which was what he wanted.
Alternate translation: [as he demonstrated this purpose in Christ]
Alternate translation: [by means of Christ]

bsb_verse_text: as a plan for the fullness of time, to bring all things in heaven and on earth together in Christ.
ult_verse_text: with a view to an administration of the fullness of time, to bring all the things together in Christ, the things in the heavens and the things on earth, in him,

notes.note: A new sentence could be started here. Alternate translation: [He did this with a view to an administration] or [He did this, thinking about a stewardship]
Alternate translation: [when the time is right] or [at the time that he has appointed]
Alternate translation: [under his rule] or [under his authority]

bsb_verse_text: In Him we were also chosen as God’s own, having been predestined according to the plan of Him who works out everything by the counsel of His will,
ult_verse_text: in whom we were also allotted as a possession. We were predestined according to the purpose of the one working out everything according to the counsel of his will,

notes.note: Both pronouns **we** and **We** are inclusive in this verse. Paul is referring to all Christians, who were predestined to belong to Christ. In [verses 12](../01/12.md) and [13](../01/13.md) he will divide this group into “we” (exclusive) Jewish Christians and “you” Gentile Christians.
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. This could mean: (1) God also chose us to be his possession. (2) God also chose us to be heirs.
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God chose us ahead of time] or [God chose us long ago]

bsb_verse_text: in order that we, who were the first to hope in Christ, would be for the praise of His glory.
ult_verse_text: so that we, the ones having first hoped in Christ, would be for the praise of his glory.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἡμᾶς & τοὺς προηλπικότας ἐν τῷ Χριστῷ
notes.note: Here, the word **we** is exclusive and refers to the Jewish believers who first heard the good news, not the believers at Ephesus.

notes.orig_language_quote: εἰς τὸ εἶναι ἡμᾶς, εἰς ἔπαινον δόξης αὐτοῦ
notes.note: Alternate translation: [so that we … would live to praise him for his glory]

bsb_verse_text: And in Him, having heard and believed the word of truth—the gospel of your salvation—you were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit,
ult_verse_text: In him, you also, having heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation, and having believed in him, were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit,

notes.note: Paul has been speaking in the previous two verses about himself and the other Jewish believers, but now he begins speaking about the Ephesian believers.
This could mean: (1) the message about the truth. (2) the true message.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐσφραγίσθητε τῷ Πνεύματι τῆς ἐπαγγελίας, τῷ Ἁγίῳ
notes.note: In this metaphor Paul pictures the **Holy Spirit** as a seal, comparing him to the wax that was placed on a letter and stamped with a symbol representing the person who wrote the letter. Paul uses this custom as a picture to show how God has used the Holy Spirit to assure us that we belong to him. Alternate translation: [God has placed the Holy Spirit that he promised on you as if he were a seal]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God has sealed you]

bsb_verse_text: who is the pledge of our inheritance until the redemption of those who are God’s possession, to the praise of His glory.
ult_verse_text: who is a down payment of our inheritance until the redemption of the full possession, to the praise of his glory.

notes.note: Receiving that which God has promised is spoken of in terms of one inheriting property or wealth from a family member. Alternate translation: [an initial portion that we will receive from what God has promised] or [a guarantee that we will receive what God has promised to give us]

bsb_verse_text: For this reason, ever since I heard about your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love for all the saints,
ult_verse_text: Because of this, I also, having heard about your faith in the Lord Jesus and the love\f + \ft Some manuscripts do not include\fqa love\fqa*, but the best manuscripts include it.\f*

notes.note: The connecting phrase **Because of this** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that the Ephesians had believed the gospel and had been sealed by the Holy Spirit. The result is that Paul praises God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

bsb_verse_text: I have not stopped giving thanks for you, remembering you in my prayers,
ult_verse_text: I have not stopped giving thanks for you, making mention {of you} in my prayers,

notes.note: Paul is using a figure of speech here that expresses a strongly positive meaning by using a negative word, **not**, together with an expression that is the opposite of the intended meaning. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express the positive meaning. Paul uses **not stopped** to emphasize that he continues to thank God. Alternate translation: [I continue to thank God]
Paul uses this exaggeration to emphasize that he thanks God very often. Alternate translation: [I continue to thank God] or [I often thank God]

bsb_verse_text: that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the glorious Father, may give you a spirit of wisdom and revelation in your knowledge of Him.
ult_verse_text: so that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, would give to you a spirit of wisdom and revelation in the knowledge of him,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that Paul prays for the Ephesians. The result is that God would enlighten the Ephesians about all that he has done for them through Christ. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

notes.orig_language_quote: πνεῦμα σοφίας καὶ ἀποκαλύψεως, ἐν ἐπιγνώσει αὐτοῦ
notes.note: Alternate translation: [spiritual wisdom to understand his revelation]

bsb_verse_text: I ask that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened, so that you may know the hope of His calling, the riches of His glorious inheritance in the saints,
ult_verse_text: the eyes of your heart having been enlightened {for} you to know what is the hope of his calling {and} what {are} the riches of the glory of his inheritance in the saints,

notes.note: Here, **heart** refers to a person’s mind or thinking. Alternate translation: [that you may gain understanding]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [that God may give you understanding] or [that God may enlighten your mind]
The phrase **eyes of your heart** is a metaphor for one’s ability to gain understanding. Alternate translation: [that you may gain understanding and be enlightened]
Alternate translation: [may be made to see]

Paul assumes that his readers will understand that the **calling** of God refers to his choosing people to believe in him. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [that you have because he chose you to be his people]
Receiving what God has promised to believers is spoken of as if one were inheriting property and wealth from a family member.
Alternate translation: [those whom he has set apart for himself] or [those who belong completely to him]

bsb_verse_text: and the surpassing greatness of His power to us who believe. These are in accordance with the working of His mighty strength,
ult_verse_text: and what {is} the incomparable greatness of his power toward us, the ones believing, according to the working of the force of his strength,

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸ ὑπερβάλλον μέγεθος τῆς δυνάμεως αὐτοῦ
notes.note: Alternate translation: [God’s power, which is far beyond all other power]
Alternate translation: [for us who believe]

notes.orig_language_quote: τὴν ἐνέργειαν τοῦ κράτους τῆς ἰσχύος αὐτοῦ
notes.note: Alternate translation: [his great power that is at work for us]
The words **force** and **strength** have very similar meanings and may be combined. Alternate translation: [of his great strength]

bsb_verse_text: which He exerted in Christ when He raised Him from the dead and seated Him at His right hand in the heavenly realms,
ult_verse_text: which he worked in Christ, having raised him from the dead and seated {him} at his right hand in the heavenly places,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [when he made him alive again]
This expression describes all **dead** people together in the underworld. To come back from among them speaks of becoming alive again. Alternate translation: [from among all those who have died]

notes.orig_language_quote: καθίσας ἐν δεξιᾷ αὐτοῦ, ἐν τοῖς ἐπουρανίοις
notes.note: The one who sits at the **right hand** of a king sits at his right side and rules with all the authority of the king at whose right hand or side he sits. This is a metonym of location that represents the authority that the person in that location possesses. Alternate translation: [gave him all authority to rule from heaven]
To sit at the **right hand** of God is a symbolic action meaning “receiving great honor and authority from God.” Alternate translation: [seated him in the place of honor and authority beside him]
The word **heavenly** refers to the place where God is. See how you translated this in [Ephesians 1:3](../01/03.md).

bsb_verse_text: far above all rule and authority, power and dominion, and every name that is named, not only in the present age but also in the one to come.
ult_verse_text: far above all rule and authority and power and dominion and every name being named, not only in this age, but also in the one coming.

notes.orig_language_quote: ὑπεράνω πάσης ἀρχῆς, καὶ ἐξουσίας, καὶ δυνάμεως, καὶ κυριότητος
notes.note: These are all terms for the ranks of supernatural beings, both angelic and demonic. If your language does not have four different terms for rulers or authorities, you can combine them. Alternate translation: [far above all types of supernatural beings]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. This could mean: (1) every name that man gives. (2) every name that God gives.
Here, **name** could refer to: (1) a title. (2) a position of authority.
Alternate translation: [at this time]
Alternate translation: [in the future]

bsb_verse_text: And God put everything under His feet and made Him head over everything for the church,
ult_verse_text: And he put all things under his feet and gave him {as} head over all things to the church,

notes.note: Here, **feet** represents Christ’s lordship, authority, and power. Alternate translation: [under Christ’s power]
Here, **head** is a metaphor that refers to the leader or the one who is in charge. Alternate translation: [ruler over all things]

bsb_verse_text: which is His body, the fullness of Him who fills all in all.
ult_verse_text: which is his body, the fullness of the one filling all in all.

notes.note: Just as the head ([verse 22](../01/22.md)) rules all things pertaining to a human body, so Christ is the head of the church **body**.

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ τὰ πάντα ἐν πᾶσιν πληρουμένου
notes.note: Alternate translation: [for Christ fills the church with his life and power just as he gives life to all things]
This could have: (1) a passive sense, which would mean that Christ fills or completes the church. (2) an active sense, which would mean that the church completes Christ (as a body completes a head).

bsb_verse_text: And you were dead in your trespasses and sins,
ult_verse_text: And you were dead in your trespasses and sins,

notes.note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nPaul reminds the believers of their past and the way they now are before God.

notes.orig_language_quote: ὑμᾶς ὄντας νεκροὺς τοῖς παραπτώμασιν καὶ ταῖς ἁμαρτίαις ὑμῶν
notes.note: This shows how the inability of a sinful person to obey God is similar to a **dead** person’s inability to respond physically. Alternate translation: [you were spiritually dead, unable to do anything but sin]

notes.orig_language_quote: τοῖς παραπτώμασιν καὶ ταῖς ἁμαρτίαις ὑμῶν
notes.note: The words **trespasses** and **sins** have similar meanings. Paul uses them together to emphasize the greatness of the people’s sin. If your language has just one word for this, the two words can be combined. Alternate translation: [your many sins]

notes.orig_language_quote: τοῖς παραπτώμασιν καὶ ταῖς ἁμαρτίαις ὑμῶν
notes.note: The words **trespasses** and **sins** are abstract nouns that represent actions. You could use an adjective or a verb for this if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [because of the sinful things that you did] or [because you were always sinning against God]

bsb_verse_text: in which you used to walk when you conformed to the ways of this world and of the ruler of the power of the air, the spirit who is now at work in the sons of disobedience.
ult_verse_text: in which you once walked according to the age of this world, according to the ruler of the authorities of the air, the spirit that is now working in the sons of disobedience,

notes.note: Here, “walk” is a metaphor for the way a person lives. Alternate translation: [which is how you lived] or [which you did habitually]

notes.orig_language_quote: κατὰ τὸν αἰῶνα τοῦ κόσμου τούτου
notes.note: The apostles often used **world** to refer to the selfish behaviors and corrupt values of the people living in this world. Alternate translation: [according to the values of people living in the world] or [following the principles of this present world]

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸν ἄρχοντα τῆς ἐξουσίας τοῦ ἀέρος
notes.note: Paul assumes that his readers will understand that this phrase refers to the devil or Satan. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [Satan, the ruler of the authorities of the air]
Alternate translation: [the spirit of Satan, who is currently working]
Alternate translation: [people who routinely disobey God]

bsb_verse_text: All of us also lived among them at one time, fulfilling the cravings of our flesh and indulging its desires and thoughts. Like the rest, we were by nature children of wrath.
ult_verse_text: in which we all also once lived in the evil desires of our flesh, fulfilling the desires of the body and of the minds. And we were by nature children of wrath, as also the rest.

notes.orig_language_quote: τὰ θελήματα τῆς σαρκὸς καὶ τῶν διανοιῶν
notes.note: The words **body** and **minds** represent the entire person. Alternate translation: [the selfish things that people want to do]
Alternate translation: [people with whom God is angry]

bsb_verse_text: But because of His great love for us, God, who is rich in mercy,
ult_verse_text: But God being rich in mercy because of his great love with which he loved us,

notes.note: The connecting word **But** introduces a contrast relationship. The love and mercy of God is in sharp contrast to the evil way the Ephesians lived before they believed in God.
The word **mercy** is an abstract noun. Alternate translation: [God is abundantly merciful] or [God is very kind to us]

notes.orig_language_quote: διὰ τὴν πολλὴν ἀγάπην αὐτοῦ, ἣν ἠγάπησεν ἡμᾶς
notes.note: The word **love** is an abstract noun. Alternate translation: [because he loved us so very much]

bsb_verse_text: made us alive with Christ even when we were dead in our trespasses. It is by grace you have been saved!
ult_verse_text: and we being dead in the trespasses, he made us alive together in Christ—by grace you have been saved—

notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God saved you by being gracious to you]
The word **grace** is an abstract noun. Alternate translation: [God saved you by being extremely kind to you] or [God saved you as a free gift]

bsb_verse_text: And God raised us up with Christ and seated us with Him in the heavenly realms in Christ Jesus,
ult_verse_text: and raised us up with {him} and seated us with {him} in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus,

notes.note: Here, **raised up** is an idiom for causing someone who has died to become alive again.

This could mean: (1) because God has caused Christ to come alive again, God has already given Paul and the believers in Ephesus new spiritual life. Alternate translation: [God has given us new life because we belong to Christ]; (2) because God has caused Christ to come alive again, the believers in Ephesus can know that after they die they will live with Christ, and Paul can speak of the believers living again as if it has already happened. Alternate translation: [we can be sure that God will give us life just as he has caused Christ to come alive again]

Paul talks about the believers as already **seated** in heaven with Christ because, although it is something that will happen in the future, it was guaranteed by what Christ did in the past. Alternate translation: [it is as though God has already seated us next to Christ]
The phrase **heavenly places** refers to the place where God is. See how this is translated in [Ephesians 1:3](../01/03.md). Alternate translation: [in the supernatural world]

The phrase **in Christ Jesus** and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.

bsb_verse_text: in order that in the coming ages He might display the surpassing riches of His grace, demonstrated by His kindness to us in Christ Jesus.
ult_verse_text: so that in the ages that are coming he might show the immeasurably great riches of his grace in his kindness to us in Christ Jesus.

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of God raising up believers and seating them in heaven with Christ is to show the extent of his grace in Christ.
Alternate translation: [in the future]

bsb_verse_text: For it is by grace you have been saved through faith, and this not from yourselves; it is the gift of God,
ult_verse_text: For by grace you have been saved through faith, and this {is} not from yourselves; {it is} the gift of God,

notes.note: The connecting word **For** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that the Ephesians had been saved by God and not by their own good works. The result is that people would see the grace of God to us in Christ. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

notes.orig_language_quote: τῇ γὰρ χάριτί ἐστε σεσῳσμένοι διὰ πίστεως
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God saved you by grace because of your faith in him]
See how you translated this phrase in [Ephesians 2:5](../02/05.md).
The pronoun **this** refers back to **by grace you have been saved by faith**.

bsb_verse_text: not by works, so that no one can boast.
ult_verse_text: not from works, so that no one may boast.

notes.orig_language_quote: οὐκ ἐξ ἔργων, ἵνα μή τις καυχήσηται
notes.note: Paul is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words from earlier in the sentence if it would be clearer in your language. You may want to start a new sentence here. Alternate translation: [Salvation does not come from works, so that no one may boast] or [God does not save a person because of what that person does, so no one can boast and say that he earned his salvation]

The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of God for saving believers by grace instead of by their works is that no person might boast, speaking as if they saved themselves.

bsb_verse_text: For we are God’s workmanship, created in Christ Jesus to do good works, which God prepared in advance as our way of life.
ult_verse_text: For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works that God prepared beforehand, so that we would walk in them.

notes.note: The connecting word **For** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that God is the one who created us to do any good works that we do. The result is that people cannot boast. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

The phrase **in Christ Jesus** and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of God creating us as he did is that we would do the good works that he intended for us to do.
To **walk** on a path is a metaphor for how a person lives his life. Here, **in them** refers to the **good works.** Alternate translation: [we would always and continually do those good deeds]

bsb_verse_text: Therefore remember that formerly you who are Gentiles in the flesh and called uncircumcised by the so-called circumcision (that done in the body by human hands)—
ult_verse_text: Therefore, remember that once you {were} Gentiles in the flesh, the ones being called “uncircumcised” by the ones being called “circumcised” in the flesh, performed by human hands.

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that they were saved by God and not by anything they had done on their own. The result is that the Ephesians would remember that they were once separated from God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
Here, **Gentiles** refers to people who were not born Jewish.
Non-Jewish people were not circumcised as babies, so the Jews considered them people who do not follow any of God’s laws. Alternate translation: [uncircumcised pagans]
This was another term for Jewish people because all male infants were **circumcised**. Alternate translation: [circumcised people]
You can translate this with an active form. Alternate translation: [by what people call] or [by those whom people call]

bsb_verse_text: remember that at that time you were separate from Christ, alienated from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers to the covenants of the promise, without hope and without God in the world.
ult_verse_text: For at that time you were apart from Christ, excluded from the community of Israel, and strangers to the covenants of the promise, having no hope and without God in the world.

notes.note: The connecting word **For** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that they were not part of the Jews, who were circumcised. The result is that the Gentile Ephesians were separated from God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
Alternate translation: [unbelievers]
Paul speaks to the Gentile believers as if they had been foreigners, kept out of the land of God’s **covenants** and **promise**.

bsb_verse_text: But now in Christ Jesus you who once were far away have been brought near through the blood of Christ.
ult_verse_text: But now in Christ Jesus you, the ones once being far away have been brought near by the blood of Christ.

notes.note: The connecting word **But** introduces a contrast relationship. The current condition of the Ephesian Gentile believers, after they believed in Christ, is that they are near to God. That is in contrast to their previous condition, before they believed in Christ, of being separated from God.

notes.orig_language_quote: ὑμεῖς οἵ ποτε ὄντες μακρὰν, ἐγενήθητε ἐγγὺς ἐν τῷ αἵματι τοῦ Χριστοῦ
notes.note: Not belonging to God due to sin is spoken of as **being far away** from God. Belonging to God because of **the blood of Christ** is spoken of as being **brought near** to God. Alternate translation: [you who once did not belong to God now belong to God because of the blood of Christ]
The **blood of Christ** is a metonym for his death. Alternate translation: [by Christ’s death] or [when Christ died for us]

bsb_verse_text: For He Himself is our peace, who has made the two one and has torn down the dividing wall of hostility
ult_verse_text: For he himself is our peace, the one having made the two one and destroyed in his flesh the middle wall of partition, the hostility.

notes.note: The connecting word **For** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that Christ himself joined them to the Jewish believers. The result is that the Ephesian Gentile believers were brought near to God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
Alternate translation: [Jesus gives us his peace]
The word **our** refers to Paul and his readers and so, it is inclusive.
Alternate translation: [who made the Jews and Gentiles one]
The phrase **his flesh,** his physical body, is a metonym for his body dying. Alternate translation: [by the death of his body on the cross]

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸ μεσότοιχον τοῦ φραγμοῦ & τὴν ἔχθραν
notes.note: The **hostility** between the Jews and Gentiles is compared to a **wall**. Alternate translation: [the hostility that was like a wall that separated them]

bsb_verse_text: by abolishing in His flesh the law of commandments and decrees. He did this to create in Himself one new man out of the two, thus making peace
ult_verse_text: He abolished the law of the commandments in regulations so that he might make the two into one new man in himself, making peace,

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸν νόμον τῶν ἐντολῶν ἐν δόγμασιν καταργήσας
notes.note: Paul assumes that his readers will understand that Jesus’ blood satisfies the law of Moses so that both the Jews and Gentiles can live at peace in God. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [He took away the requirements in the law of Moses]
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of Christ in abolishing the law was to join the Jews and the Gentiles together into one group.
Paul talks about the unity of Jews and Gentiles as if they had become **one** person. Alternate translation: [a single new people]

Being joined to Christ is what makes reconciliation possible between Jews and Gentiles. Paul describes this relationship as though Christ surrounded all of us. Alternate translation: [because he made it possible]

bsb_verse_text: and reconciling both of them to God in one body through the cross, by which He put to death their hostility.
ult_verse_text: and so that he might reconcile both to God as one body through the cross, putting to death the hostility in it.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [so that Christ might bring the Jews and the Gentiles together in peace]
The church is often pictured as the **body** of Christ, who is its head. Here it is comprised of both Jews and Gentiles.
The **cross** here represents Christ’s death on the cross. Alternate translation: [by means of Christ’s death on the cross]

Ending their **hostility** is spoken of as if Christ killed their hostility. By dying on the cross, Jesus eliminated the reason for Jews and Gentiles to be hostile toward each other. Neither are now required to live according to the law of Moses. Alternate translation: [stopping them from hating one another]

bsb_verse_text: He came and preached peace to you who were far away and peace to those who were near.
ult_verse_text: And he came {and} proclaimed peace to you, the ones far away and peace to the ones near,

notes.note: Paul tells the Ephesians that Gentile believers are also now just as much a part of God’s people as are Jewish believers. The Jewish apostles and prophets are theirs, as is Christ, and they all form a temple for God in the Spirit. Alternate translation: [and announced the gospel of peace] or [declaring the gospel of peace]
Paul pictures the Gentiles (non-Jews), who were not part of God’s people, as though they were physically distant from God.
Paul pictures the Jews, who were God’s people by birth, as though they were physically close to God.

bsb_verse_text: For through Him we both have access to the Father by one Spirit.
ult_verse_text: for through him both have access in one Spirit to the Father.

notes.orig_language_quote: ὅτι δι’ αὐτοῦ ἔχομεν τὴν προσαγωγὴν, οἱ ἀμφότεροι
notes.note: Here, **both** refers to Paul and the rest of the believing Jews, and it also refers to the believing non-Jews.

The connecting word **for** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that he himself is the one who enabled both Jew and Gentile to come to the Father. The result is that Christ proclaimed peace to both the Jews and the Gentiles. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

The implication is that all believers, both Jewish and Gentile, are enabled to enter into the presence of God the Father by the same Holy **Spirit**. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [by means of the same Spirit]

bsb_verse_text: Therefore you are no longer strangers and foreigners, but fellow citizens with the saints and members of God’s household,
ult_verse_text: So then, you are no longer strangers and foreigners. Instead, you are fellow citizens with the saints and {members} of the household of God,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **So then** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that Christ gave them access to God through the Spirit. The result is that the Ephesian believers are no longer separated from God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
The words **strangers** and **foreigners** have very similar meanings and may be combined. Alternate translation: [people who had no relationship to God]

The connecting word **Instead** introduces a contrast relationship. The previous separation of the Ephesians from God is in contrast to their current status as citizens of the kingdom of God and members of his household.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐστὲ συνπολῖται τῶν ἁγίων καὶ οἰκεῖοι τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: Paul is again speaking of the spiritual condition of Gentiles after they become believers as he would speak about foreigners becoming **citizens** of a different nation.

bsb_verse_text: built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets, with Christ Jesus Himself as the cornerstone.
ult_verse_text: having been built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Christ Jesus himself being the cornerstone,

notes.note: Paul speaks of God’s people as if they were a building. Christ is the cornerstone, the apostles are the **foundation**, and the believers are the structure. Alternate translation: [you depend on the teaching]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God has built you]

bsb_verse_text: In Him the whole building is fitted together and grows into a holy temple in the Lord.
ult_verse_text: in whom the whole building, being fit together, grows into a holy temple in the Lord,

notes.orig_language_quote: πᾶσα οἰκοδομὴ συναρμολογουμένη, αὔξει εἰς ναὸν ἅγιον
notes.note: Paul continues to speak of Christ’s family as if it were a **building**. In the same way that a builder fits stones together while building, so Christ is fitting us together. Alternate translation: [all of us, as we grow together, become a holy group that worships God]
These metaphors express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him. Alternate translation: [In Christ … in the Lord Jesus]

bsb_verse_text: And in Him you too are being built together into a dwelling place for God in His Spirit.
ult_verse_text: in whom you also are being built together into a dwelling place for God in the Spirit.

notes.note: You can translate this as “in Christ,” which is a metaphor that expresses the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.

notes.orig_language_quote: καὶ ὑμεῖς συνοικοδομεῖσθε, εἰς κατοικητήριον τοῦ Θεοῦ ἐν Πνεύματι
notes.note: This describes how believers are being put together to become a **place** where **God** will permanently live through the power of the Holy **Spirit**. Alternate translation: [you also are being joined to this group where God lives by his Spirit]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God is also building you together]

bsb_verse_text: For this reason I, Paul, the prisoner of Christ Jesus for the sake of you Gentiles...
ult_verse_text: For this reason I, Paul, the prisoner of Christ Jesus on behalf of you Gentiles,

notes.note: To make clear the hidden truth about the church to believers, Paul refers back to the oneness of Jews and Gentiles and how believers from both groups form part of the one group that worships God, like the stones that form one temple. The connecting phrase **For this reason** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is what Paul talked about in Chapter 2, that Christ showed his grace by removing the division between Jews and Gentiles and making them into one group. The result is that Paul prays for the Gentiles. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result. Alternate translation: [This is why]

You may need to make explicit what the reason is. Alternate translation: [Because of God’s grace to you,] You may also need to make explicit here what the result is, as in the UST, because Paul does not state the result, that he prays for them, until [3:14](../03/14.md).
Alternate translation: [the one who is in prison because I serve Christ Jesus]

bsb_verse_text: Surely you have heard about the stewardship of God’s grace that was given to me for you,
ult_verse_text: if indeed you have heard of the stewardship of the grace of God that was given to me for you,

notes.orig_language_quote: τὴν οἰκονομίαν τῆς χάριτος τοῦ Θεοῦ, τῆς δοθείσης μοι εἰς ὑμᾶς
notes.note: Here, **grace** could mean: (1) the gift of the gospel that Paul is bringing to the Gentiles. Alternate translation: [the responsibility that God gave me to bring his grace to you]; (2) the gift to Paul of being the steward of the gospel for the Gentiles. Alternate translation: [the responsibility that God graciously gave me for your benefit]

bsb_verse_text: that is, the mystery made known to me by revelation, as I have already written briefly.
ult_verse_text: according to a revelation made known to me, the mystery about which I already wrote in brief.

notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [according to what God revealed to me]
Paul refers here to another letter that he had written to these people.

bsb_verse_text: which was not made known to men in other generations as it has now been revealed by the Spirit to God’s holy apostles and prophets.
ult_verse_text: which in other generations was not made known to the sons of men as it now has been revealed by the Spirit to his holy apostles and prophets—

notes.orig_language_quote: ὃ ἑτέραις γενεαῖς οὐκ ἐγνωρίσθη τοῖς υἱοῖς τῶν ἀνθρώπων
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God did not make these things known to people in the past]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [but now the Spirit has revealed it] or [but now the Spirit has made it known]

bsb_verse_text: This mystery is that through the gospel the Gentiles are fellow heirs, fellow members of the body, and fellow partakers of the promise in Christ Jesus.
ult_verse_text: that the Gentiles are to be fellow heirs and fellow members of the body, and fellow partakers of the promise in Christ Jesus through the gospel,

notes.orig_language_quote: εἶναι τὰ ἔθνη, συνκληρονόμα & διὰ τοῦ εὐαγγελίου
notes.note: Paul assumes that his readers will understand **that the Gentiles are to be fellow heirs.** You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. This is the hidden truth that Paul began to explain in the previous verse. The **Gentiles** who receive Christ also receive everything that the Jewish believers receive from God.

Paul assumes that his readers will understand that **Gentiles** are to be **fellow members of the body**. The church is often referred to as “the body of Christ.” You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [members of the body of Christ]

The phrase **in Christ Jesus** and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.

This could mean: (1) because of the **gospel**, the Gentiles are fellow sharers in the promise. (2) because of the **gospel**, the Gentiles are fellow heirs and members of the body and fellow sharers in the promise.

bsb_verse_text: Though I am less than the least of all the saints, this grace was given me: to preach to the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ,
ult_verse_text: To me—the least of all the saints—this grace was given, to preach to the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ,

notes.note: Paul speaks of everything that Christ offers as something so physically vast that it cannot be fully explored. Alternate translation: [unable to be completely known]
Paul speaks of the truth about **Christ** and the blessings he brings as if they were material wealth.

bsb_verse_text: and to illuminate for everyone the stewardship of this mystery, which for ages past was kept hidden in God, who created all things.
ult_verse_text: and to reveal for everyone what {is} the administration of the mystery that was hidden from the ages in God, the one having created all things,

notes.orig_language_quote: τοῦ μυστηρίου, τοῦ ἀποκεκρυμμένου ἀπὸ τῶν αἰώνων ἐν τῷ Θεῷ, τῷ τὰ πάντα κτίσαντι
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [of God, who created all things, kept this plan hidden for long ages in the past]

bsb_verse_text: His purpose was that now, through the church, the manifold wisdom of God should be made known to the rulers and authorities in the heavenly realms,
ult_verse_text: so that now through the church the multifaceted wisdom of God might be made known to the rulers and to the authorities in the heavenly places,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of God revealing the mystery of the church to Paul is to enable the rulers in the heavenly places to see the wisdom of God.

notes.orig_language_quote: γνωρισθῇ & ταῖς ἀρχαῖς καὶ ταῖς ἐξουσίαις ἐν τοῖς ἐπουρανίοις & ἡ πολυποίκιλος σοφία τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God may make his great wisdom known to the rulers and authorities in the heavenly places]

The words **rulers** and **authorities** share similar meanings. Paul uses them together to emphasize that every spiritual being will know God’s wisdom. If your language does not have two words for this, you can use one. Alternate translation: [ruling authorities]
The phrase **heavenly places** refers to the place where God is. See how this is translated in [Ephesians 1:3](../01/03.md). Alternate translation: [in the supernatural world]
Paul talks of God’s **wisdom** as though it were an object with many surfaces. Alternate translation: [the complex wisdom of God] or [how extremely wise God is]

bsb_verse_text: according to the eternal purpose that He accomplished in Christ Jesus our Lord.
ult_verse_text: according to the eternal purpose that he accomplished in Christ Jesus our Lord,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [in keeping with the eternal plan] or [consistent with the eternal plan]

bsb_verse_text: In Him and through faith in Him we may enter God’s presence with boldness and confidence.
ult_verse_text: in whom we have boldness and access with confidence through faith in him.

notes.note: In this section of the prayer, Paul praises God in his sufferings and prays for these Ephesian believers. The two words **boldness** and **access** work together to express one idea. Alternate translation: [bold access] or [boldness to enter]

It may be helpful to state explicitly that this **access** is into God’s presence. Alternate translation: [access into God’s presence with confidence] or [freedom to enter into God’s presence with confidence]
Alternate translation: [certainty] or [assurance]

bsb_verse_text: So I ask you not to be discouraged because of my sufferings for you, which are your glory.
ult_verse_text: Therefore, I ask you not to be discouraged by my sufferings for you, which is your glory.

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that the believers have access to Christ with confidence. The result is that the believers will not be discouraged. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

notes.orig_language_quote: ὑπὲρ ὑμῶν, ἥτις ἐστὶν δόξα ὑμῶν
notes.note: Here, **your glory** is a metonym for the salvation and eternal life that the Ephesians will have because of Paul’s work of telling them about Christ, which resulted in his suffering in prison. You can state this as a new sentence. Alternate translation: [for you. They bring you a wonderful benefit] or [for you. They result in your salvation]

bsb_verse_text: ... for this reason I bow my knees before the Father,
ult_verse_text: For this reason I bend my knees to the Father,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **For this reason** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that Paul’s sufferings have caused glory for the believers. The result is that Paul prays to the Father. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
You may need to make explicit what the reason is. Alternate translation: [Because God has done all this for you]

notes.orig_language_quote: κάμπτω τὰ γόνατά μου πρὸς τὸν Πατέρα
notes.note: Bent **knees** are a picture of the whole person in an attitude of prayer. Alternate translation: [I bow down in prayer to the Father] or [I humbly pray to the Father]

bsb_verse_text: from whom every family in heaven and on earth derives its name.
ult_verse_text: from whom every family in heaven and on earth is named,

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐξ οὗ πᾶσα πατριὰ ἐν οὐρανοῖς καὶ ἐπὶ γῆς ὀνομάζεται
notes.note: The act of naming here probably also represents the act of creating. Alternate translation: [who created and named every family in heaven and on earth]

bsb_verse_text: I ask that out of the riches of His glory He may strengthen you with power through His Spirit in your inner being,
ult_verse_text: so that he would grant you, according to the riches of his glory, to be strengthened with power through his Spirit in the inner man,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of Paul’s prayer is that the Ephesian believers would be strengthened by God in their faith and love.

notes.orig_language_quote: δῷ ὑμῖν κατὰ τὸ πλοῦτος τῆς δόξης αὐτοῦ, δυνάμει κραταιωθῆναι
notes.note: Alternate translation: [God, because he is so great and powerful, would allow you to become strong with his power]
Alternate translation: [he would give]

bsb_verse_text: so that Christ may dwell in your hearts through faith. Then you, being rooted and grounded in love,
ult_verse_text: that Christ may live in your hearts through faith, being rooted and grounded in love,

notes.note: Paul continues the prayer he began in [Ephesians 3:14](../03/14.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: κατοικῆσαι τὸν Χριστὸν διὰ τῆς πίστεως ἐν ταῖς καρδίαις ὑμῶν ἐν ἀγάπῃ, ἐρριζωμένοι καὶ τεθεμελιωμένοι
notes.note: With the phrase, **that Christ may live** Paul continues the prayer he began in [Ephesians 3:14](../03/14.md). This is the second item for which Paul prays that God will grant the Ephesians “according to the riches of his glory.” The first is that they would be strengthened ([Ephesians 3:16](../03/16.md)).

notes.orig_language_quote: κατοικῆσαι τὸν Χριστὸν διὰ τῆς πίστεως ἐν ταῖς καρδίαις ὑμῶν
notes.note: Here, **hearts** represent a person’s inner being, and **through** expresses the means by which Christ lives within the believer. Christ lives in the hearts of believers because God graciously allows them to have faith. Alternate translation: [that Christ may live within you because you trust in him]

Paul speaks of their faith as if it were a tree that has deep roots or a house built on a solid foundation. Alternate translation: [you will be like a firmly rooted tree and a building built on stone]

bsb_verse_text: will have power, together with all the saints, to comprehend the length and width and height and depth
ult_verse_text: so that you may be fully able to comprehend, along with all the saints, what {is} the width and length and height and depth,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that Christ would live in their hearts. The result is that the Ephesian believers would fully know the love of God and be filled with God’s fullness. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

With the introductory phrase, Paul moves to the third item, **to comprehend**, for which he bends his knees and prays; the first is that God will grant that they be strengthened ([Ephesians 3:16](../03/16.md)) and the second is that Christ may live in their hearts through faith ([Ephesians 3:17](../03/17.md)).
Alternate translation: [all the believers in Christ]

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸ πλάτος, καὶ μῆκος, καὶ ὕψος, καὶ βάθος
notes.note: In this metaphor Paul pictures something that is not physical or measurable as something that is physical but stretches out in all directions and, thus, is very large. This could refer to: (1) the intensity of Christ’s love for us. Alternate translation: [how very much Christ loves us]; (2) the greatness of God’s wisdom. Alternate translation: [how very wise God is]

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸ πλάτος, καὶ μῆκος, καὶ ὕψος, καὶ βάθος
notes.note: It may be necessary to state explicitly what these words refer to. If so, you could combine this with the phrase from the next verse. Alternate translation: [the width and length and height and depth of, and truly know the love of Christ] or [the width and length and height and depth of the love of Christ, and truly know it]

bsb_verse_text: of the love of Christ, and to know this love that surpasses knowledge, that you may be filled with all the fullness of God.
ult_verse_text: and to know the love of Christ surpassing knowledge, so that you may be filled with all the fullness of God.

notes.orig_language_quote: γνῶναί τε τὴν & ἀγάπην τοῦ Χριστοῦ
notes.note: With the conjunction **and**, Paul continues the idea from the previous verse. They both refer to knowing the greatness of the love of Christ. Alternate translation: [that you can know how great Christ’s love for us is]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἵνα πληρωθῆτε εἰς πᾶν τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: This is the fourth item for which Paul bends his knees and prays ([Ephesians 3:14](../03/14.md)). The first is that they would “be strengthened” ([Ephesians 3:16](../03/16.md)), the second is that “Christ would live in their hearts through faith” ([Ephesians 3:17](../03/17.md)), and the third is that they “could comprehend Christ’s love” ([Ephesians 3:18](../03/18.md)).

notes.orig_language_quote: ἵνα πληρωθῆτε εἰς πᾶν τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: In this metaphor Paul pictures the Ephesian believers as containers into which **God** can pour himself. Alternate translation: [so God can give you everything that he has to give you]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [so that God can fill you]

notes.orig_language_quote: εἰς πᾶν τὸ πλήρωμα τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **fullness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [with everything that God is full of]

The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that the Ephesian believers would know the love of Christ. The result is that they would be filled with the fulness of God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

bsb_verse_text: Now to Him who is able to do immeasurably more than all we ask or imagine, according to His power that is at work within us,
ult_verse_text: And to the one being able to do exceedingly abundantly above all that we ask or think, according to the power that is working in us,

notes.note: The words “we” and “us” in this book continue to include Paul and all believers.

Paul concludes his prayer by asking God to bless the Ephesian believers. You could express this as either a blessing or a prayer, in whichever way is more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Now to God, the one]

notes.orig_language_quote: ὑπὲρ πάντα, ποιῆσαι ὑπέρἐκπερισσοῦ ὧν αἰτούμεθα ἢ νοοῦμεν
notes.note: Alternate translation: [to do much more than all that we ask or think] or [to do things that are much greater than anything that we ask him for or think about]

bsb_verse_text: to Him be the glory in the church and in Christ Jesus throughout all generations, forever and ever. Amen.
ult_verse_text: to him {be} the glory in the church and in Christ Jesus to all generations forever {and} ever. Amen.

notes.orig_language_quote: αὐτῷ ἡ δόξα ἐν τῇ ἐκκλησίᾳ
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **glory**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [may God’s people glorify him] or [may God’s people praise him for how great he is]

bsb_verse_text: As a prisoner in the Lord, then, I urge you to walk in a manner worthy of the calling you have received:
ult_verse_text: Therefore I, the prisoner for the Lord, urge you to walk worthily of the calling by which you were called,

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that God will be glorified in the church for all generations. The result is that believers should walk in a way that is worthy of the Lord. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
Alternate translation: [someone who is in prison because he serves the Lord]

The phrase **to walk** is a common way to express the idea of living one’s life. Because of what Paul has been writing to the Ephesians, he now tells them how they should live their lives as believers, reemphasizing that believers are to agree with each other.
Here, **the calling** refers to the fact that God chose them to be his people. Alternate translation: [because God chose you to be his people]

bsb_verse_text: with all humility and gentleness, with patience, bearing with one another in love,
ult_verse_text: with all humility and gentleness, with patience, putting up with one another in love,

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the words **humility**, **gentleness**, and **patience**, you could express the same ideas with verbal forms. Alternate translation: [to learn to be humble, gentle, and patient]

bsb_verse_text: and with diligence to preserve the unity of the Spirit through the bond of peace.
ult_verse_text: doing your best to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.

notes.orig_language_quote: τηρεῖν τὴν ἑνότητα τοῦ Πνεύματος ἐν τῷ συνδέσμῳ τῆς εἰρήνης
notes.note: Here Paul speaks of **peace** as if it were a **bond** that ties people together. This is a metaphor for being united with other people by living peacefully with them. Alternate translation: [to live peacefully with one another and remain united as the Spirit made possible]

notes.orig_language_quote: τηρεῖν τὴν ἑνότητα τοῦ Πνεύματος ἐν τῷ συνδέσμῳ τῆς εἰρήνης
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the words **unity** and **peace**, you could express the same ideas with verbal forms. Alternate translation: [to live peacefully with one another and remain united as the Spirit made possible]

bsb_verse_text: There is one body and one Spirit, just as you were called to one hope when you were called;
ult_verse_text: {There is} one body and one Spirit, just as also you were called in one hope of your calling,

notes.note: The church is often referred to as the **body** of Christ.
Alternate translation: [only one Holy Spirit]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐκλήθητε ἐν μιᾷ ἐλπίδι τῆς κλήσεως ὑμῶν
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God called you to have one confident hope in your calling] or [there is one thing that God also chose you to be confident in and expect him to do]

bsb_verse_text: one God and Father of all, who is over all and through all and in all.
ult_verse_text: one God and Father of all, the one over all and through all and in all.

notes.orig_language_quote: Πατὴρ πάντων & ἐπὶ πάντων & διὰ πάντων & ἐν πᾶσιν
notes.note: Alternate translation: [Father of every person … over every thing … through all things … in all things]

bsb_verse_text: Now to each one of us grace has been given according to the measure of the gift of Christ.
ult_verse_text: And to each one of us this grace has been given according to the measure of the gift of Christ.

notes.note: Paul assumes that his readers will understand that the poetic material which follows is from a song that King David wrote. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers

notes.orig_language_quote: ἑνὶ & ἑκάστῳ ἡμῶν ἐδόθη ἡ χάρις
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [God has given grace to each one of us] or [God gave a gift to each believer]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἑνὶ & ἑκάστῳ ἡμῶν ἐδόθη ἡ χάρις
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **grace**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [God has given a gift to each believer]

bsb_verse_text: This is why it says: “When He ascended on high, He led captives away, and gave gifts to men.”
ult_verse_text: Therefore it says:

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that every believer has been given a spiritual gift. The result is that the Scripture says Jesus gave gifts to men. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
Alternate translation: [When Christ went up into heaven]

bsb_verse_text: What does “He ascended” mean, except that He also descended to the lower parts of the earth?
ult_verse_text: And this “He ascended,” what is it except that he also descended into the lower regions of the earth?

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Christ went up]
Alternate translation: [Christ also came down]

notes.orig_language_quote: εἰς τὰ κατώτερα μέρη τῆς γῆς
notes.note: This could refer to: (1) the **lower regions** as a part of the **earth**. (2) **the lower regions** as another way of referring to the **earth** itself. Alternate translation: [into the lower regions, the earth]

bsb_verse_text: He who descended is the very One who ascended above all the heavens, in order to fill all things.
ult_verse_text: The one having descended is also himself the one having ascended far above all the heavens, so that he might fill all things.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [so that he might be working powerfully everywhere]
Alternate translation: [he might complete] or [he might satisfy]

bsb_verse_text: And it was He who gave some to be apostles, some to be prophets, some to be evangelists, and some to be pastors and teachers,
ult_verse_text: And he himself gave the apostles, and the prophets, and the evangelists, and the pastors and teachers,

notes.note: The word translated as **pastors** here is the the same word that is translated as “shepherds” elsewhere in the ULT. It is the plural form of the word used by Jesus to refer to himself in [John 10:10](../../jhn/10/10.md), where he says that he is the “good Shepherd.” The idea here is that in a similar way to how a shepherd feeds, protects, and watches over the well-being of his flock, so pastors feed (with spiritual food) and watch over and protect the spiritual well-being of those within their church. If it would help your readers, you could indicate explicitly the meaning of the word “pastors.” Alternate translation: [spiritual shepherds] or [shepherding Christian leaders]

bsb_verse_text: to equip the saints for works of ministry and to build up the body of Christ,
ult_verse_text: for the equipping of the saints for the work of serving, for building up of the body of Christ,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [to prepare the people whom he has set apart] or [to provide the believers with what they need]
Alternate translation: [so that they can serve others]

notes.orig_language_quote: εἰς οἰκοδομὴν τοῦ σώματος τοῦ Χριστοῦ
notes.note: Paul is speaking of people who grow spiritually as if they were doing exercises to increase the strength of their physical bodies.
Alternate translation: [the improvement]
Alternate translation: [all of the members of Christ’s church] or [all those who are believers in Christ]

bsb_verse_text: until we all reach unity in the faith and in the knowledge of the Son of God, as we mature to the full measure of the stature of Christ.
ult_verse_text: until we all reach to the unity of the faith and the knowledge of the Son of God, to a mature man, to the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ,

notes.orig_language_quote: καταντήσωμεν οἱ πάντες εἰς τὴν ἑνότητα τῆς πίστεως, καὶ τῆς ἐπιγνώσεως τοῦ Υἱοῦ τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: The implication is that the believers need to know Jesus as the **Son of God** if they are to be united in **faith** and become mature as believers. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. [we all join together in our belief and relationship with Jesus the Christ]

notes.orig_language_quote: καταντήσωμεν οἱ πάντες εἰς τὴν ἑνότητα τῆς πίστεως
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **unity**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [we all become equally strong in faith] or [we all become united together in faith]

notes.orig_language_quote: καταντήσωμεν οἱ πάντες εἰς τὴν ἑνότητα τῆς πίστεως
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faith**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [become united together as believers]

notes.orig_language_quote: τῆς ἐπιγνώσεως τοῦ Υἱοῦ τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **knowledge**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [all know well the Son of God]
**Son of God** is an important title for Jesus.
Alternate translation: [to a mature believer]
Alternate translation: [fully developed] or [grown up] or [complete]

bsb_verse_text: Then we will no longer be infants, tossed about by the waves and carried around by every wind of teaching and by the clever cunning of men in their deceitful scheming.
ult_verse_text: so that we may no longer be children tossed back and forth by the waves and carried away by every wind of teaching through the trickery of men in cleverness for deceitful scheming.

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of gifted people in the church is to bring all the believers to spiritual maturity.
Paul refers to believers who have not grown spiritually as if they were **children** who have had very little experience in life. Alternate translation: [we may no longer be like children]

notes.orig_language_quote: κλυδωνιζόμενοι καὶ περιφερόμενοι παντὶ ἀνέμῳ τῆς διδασκαλίας
notes.note: Paul speaks of a believer who has not become mature and follows various wrong teachings as if that believer were a boat and the teachings were the **wind** and **waves** that move the boat in different directions on the water..

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐν τῇ κυβίᾳ τῶν ἀνθρώπων, ἐν πανουργίᾳ πρὸς τὴν μεθοδίαν τῆς πλάνης
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the words **trickery**, **cleverness**, and **scheming**, you could express the same ideas with verbal forms. Alternate translation: [by crafty people who trick believers with clever lies]

bsb_verse_text: Instead, speaking the truth in love, we will in all things grow up into Christ Himself, who is the head.
ult_verse_text: Instead, speaking truth in love, let us grow up in all things into him who is the head, {even} Christ,

notes.note: The connecting word **Instead** introduces a contrast relationship. Following every changing teaching is in contrast to becoming mature in Christ and building up his body. Use a word in your language that indicates contrast.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **truth**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [speaking truthfully]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **love**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [as the members love one another]

notes.orig_language_quote: εἰς αὐτὸν & ὅς ἐστιν ἡ κεφαλή
notes.note: Paul uses a metaphor of the human body to describe how Christ causes believers to work together in harmony as the **head** of a body causes the body parts to work together to grow in a healthy way.

bsb_verse_text: From Him the whole body, fitted and held together by every supporting ligament, grows and builds itself up in love through the work of each individual part.
ult_verse_text: from whom the whole body, being joined and held together by every supporting ligament, according to the working in measure of each individual part, causes the growth of the body for building up itself in love.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐξ οὗ πᾶν τὸ σῶμα & τὴν αὔξησιν τοῦ σώματος ποιεῖται
notes.note: Paul continues the metaphor of the believers as a human **body** with Christ as the head to describe how Christ causes believers to work together in harmony as the head of a body causes the body parts to work together to grow in a healthy way.

The word **for** indicates a purpose clause. The purpose of all of the believers working together in harmony, as the members of a human body do, is so that all believers will grow in our ability to love each other and to love God. Use a word in your language that marks this as a purpose clause.

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **love**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [as the members love one another] or [to be able to love each other more]

Paul continues the metaphor comparing the believers to a human body. A **ligament** is a strong band that connects bones or holds organs in place in the body. Just as the body is held together by strong ligaments, so the believers are held together by love that grows stronger as the body parts grow and work together.

bsb_verse_text: So I tell you this, and insist on it in the Lord, that you must no longer walk as the Gentiles do, in the futility of their thinking.
ult_verse_text: Therefore, I say this and strongly urge you in the Lord, to walk no longer as the Gentiles also walk, in futility of their minds.

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship in which Paul tells them what they should no longer do now that they, as believers, are sealed by the Holy Spirit of God. The reason is that Christ wants every believer to become spiritually mature and to serve the other believers. The result is that the Ephesian believers should no longer act as the Gentiles act. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
Alternate translation: [Because of what I have just said, I will now say something more in order to strongly encourage]
This could be: (1) referring to the authority of the Lord. (2) stating that we all belong to the Lord.

notes.orig_language_quote: μηκέτι ὑμᾶς περιπατεῖν, καθὼς καὶ τὰ ἔθνη περιπατεῖ ἐν ματαιότητι τοῦ νοὸς αὐτῶν
notes.note: Paul commonly uses this metaphor that compares walking to living one’s life. Alternate translation: [you … to stop living like the Gentiles with their worthless thoughts]

bsb_verse_text: They are darkened in their understanding and alienated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them due to the hardness of their hearts.
ult_verse_text: They have been darkened in their understanding, being alienated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them, because of the hardness of their hearts.

notes.note: This metaphor compares wrong thinking with darkness. Alternate translation: [they no longer think or reason clearly] or [they are not able to understand]

If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [Their way of thinking has become dark] or [They no longer think or reason clearly] or [They are not able to understand]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἀπηλλοτριωμένοι τῆς ζωῆς τοῦ Θεοῦ, διὰ τὴν ἄγνοιαν τὴν οὖσαν ἐν αὐτοῖς
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [because they do not know God, they cannot live the way that God wants his people to live] or [they have cut themselves off from the life of God by their ignorance]
Alternate translation: [cut off] or [separated]
Alternate translation: [lack of knowledge] or [lack of information]

notes.orig_language_quote: διὰ τὴν πώρωσιν τῆς καρδίας αὐτῶν
notes.note: The phrase **hardness of their hearts** is a metaphor that means “stubbornness.” Alternate translation: [because they are stubborn] or [because they refuse to listen to God]

The connecting word **because** introduces a reason-result relationship. The first reason is that they are ignorant of him. The result is that the Gentiles are separated from God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

Again, the connecting word **because** introduces a reason-result relationship. The second reason is that their hearts are hardened. The result is that Gentiles are separated from walking with God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

bsb_verse_text: Having lost all sense of shame, they have given themselves over to sensuality for the practice of every kind of impurity, with a craving for more.
ult_verse_text: They, being dead to all feeling, handed themselves over to sensuality for the practice of every kind of impurity with greediness.

notes.note: Paul speaks of these people as if they were objects that they themselves were giving to other people, and he speaks of the way that they want to satisfy their physical desires as if the desires were the person to whom they give themselves. Alternate translation: [have given in to every physical desire] or [only want to satisfy their physical desires]

bsb_verse_text: But this is not the way you came to know Christ.
ult_verse_text: But you did not thus learn about Christ,

notes.orig_language_quote: ὑμεῖς δὲ οὐχ οὕτως ἐμάθετε τὸν Χριστόν
notes.note: The word **thus** refers to the way that the Gentiles live, as described in [Ephesians 4:17–19](../04/17.md). Paul uses **thus** to emphasize strongly that what the believers learned from Christ was the opposite of what he just described. Alternate translation: [But what you learned about the ways of Christ was not like that] or [But what you learned about the ways of Christ was very different]

The connecting word **But** introduces a contrast relationship. The sinful way the Gentiles live is in contrast to the way that Paul taught the Ephesians to live according to the truth of Jesus. Use a connecting word in your language that marks a contrast here

bsb_verse_text: Surely you heard of Him and were taught in Him—in keeping with the truth that is in Jesus—
ult_verse_text: if indeed you have heard about him and were taught in him, as the truth is in Jesus.

notes.orig_language_quote: εἴ γε αὐτὸν ἠκούσατε καὶ ἐν αὐτῷ ἐδιδάχθητε
notes.note: Paul knows that the people to whom he is writing have **heard** and been **taught** these things. He is using irony as a form of rebuke—if they are doing things contrary to the way of Christ, they know better than that and need to stop.
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. This could mean: (1) they received instruction in his ways. (2) Jesus’ people have taught them.

notes.orig_language_quote: καθώς ἐστιν ἀλήθεια ἐν τῷ Ἰησοῦ
notes.note: Alternate translation: [as Jesus teaches us the true way to live] or [as everything about Jesus is true]

bsb_verse_text: to put off your former way of life, your old self, which is being corrupted by its deceitful desires;
ult_verse_text: You are to put aside {what} belongs to your former manner of life, the old man being corrupted according to {its} deceitful desires,

notes.orig_language_quote: ἀποθέσθαι ὑμᾶς κατὰ τὴν προτέραν ἀναστροφὴν
notes.note: Paul is speaking of moral qualities as if they were pieces of clothing. Alternate translation: [You must stop living according to your former manner of life]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἀποθέσθαι ὑμᾶς κατὰ τὴν προτέραν ἀναστροφὴν τὸν παλαιὸν ἄνθρωπον
notes.note: Paul is speaking of a way of living as if it were a person. Alternate translation: [You must stop doing the things that your former self did] or [Stop doing the things that you used to do]
The **old man** refers to the “old nature” or “former self,” the way that the person was before the person became a believer in Christ

notes.orig_language_quote: τὸν φθειρόμενον κατὰ τὰς ἐπιθυμίας τῆς ἀπάτης
notes.note: Paul is continuing to speak of a sinful way of living as if it were a person who does evil things. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when you fooled yourself into thinking that it was good to do whatever evil thing that you wanted to do]

bsb_verse_text: to be renewed in the spirit of your minds;
ult_verse_text: and to be renewed in the spirit of your minds,

notes.orig_language_quote: ἀνανεοῦσθαι & τῷ πνεύματι τοῦ νοὸς ὑμῶν
notes.note: This may be translated with an active form. Alternate translation: [to allow God to change your attitudes and thoughts] or [to allow God to give you new attitudes and thoughts]

bsb_verse_text: and to put on the new self, created to be like God in true righteousness and holiness.
ult_verse_text: and to put on the new man {that is} according to God—having been created in righteousness and holiness of the truth.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐν δικαιοσύνῃ καὶ ὁσιότητι τῆς ἀληθείας
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the words **righteousness**, **holiness**, and **truth**, you could express the same ideas with verbal forms. Alternate translation: [truly righteous and holy]

Paul continues to speak of a way of living as if it were a person, and also as if it were clothing, so that one could **put on** the **new** person like a robe. Alternate translation: [be the new person] or [start living in the new way]

bsb_verse_text: Therefore each of you must put off falsehood and speak truthfully to his neighbor, for we are all members of one another.
ult_verse_text: Therefore, putting aside the lying, let each of you speak truth with his neighbor, because we are members of one another.

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that God has created the believers as new, holy people. The result is that they would stop acting immorally like they used to live. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
Paul speaks of telling lies as if they were objects that the believers could set aside. Alternate translation: [no longer telling lies] or [instead of telling lies]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **truth**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [each of you should speak truthfully]

The connecting word **because** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that believers are members of the same body of Christ. The result is that believers should speak the truth to each other. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
