Paul speaks of the close union of believers with each other as if they were each part of one single body. Alternate translation: [we belong to one another] or [we are all members of God’s family]

bsb_verse_text: “Be angry, yet do not sin.” Do not let the sun set upon your anger,
ult_verse_text: Be angry and do not sin. Do not let the sun go down on your indignation,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [You may get angry, but do not sin] or [If you become angry, do not sin]

notes.orig_language_quote: ὁ ἥλιος μὴ ἐπιδυέτω ἐπὶ παροργισμῷ ὑμῶν
notes.note: The **sun** going **down** represents nightfall or the end of the day. Alternate translation: [You must stop being angry before night comes] or [Let go of your anger before the day ends]

bsb_verse_text: and do not give the devil a foothold.
ult_verse_text: nor give an opportunity to the devil.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and do not give the devil an opportunity to lead you into sin]

bsb_verse_text: He who has been stealing must steal no longer, but must work, doing good with his own hands, that he may have something to share with the one in need.
ult_verse_text: The thief must steal no longer. But rather, he must labor, working good with his hands, so that he may have something to share with the ones having need.

notes.note: The connecting phrase **But rather** introduces a contrast relationship. The way a former thief should work hard to have something to share with others is in contrast to the way he formerly stole for himself.
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of working hard with ones own hands is to be able to meet the needs of others.

bsb_verse_text: Let no unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building up the one in need and bringing grace to those who listen.
ult_verse_text: Do not let any corrupt talk come out from your mouth, but whatever {is} good for building up of the {one in} need, so that it might give grace to the hearers,

notes.note: The phrase **corrupt talk** refers to speech that is cruel or rude. If your readers would not be familiar with this term, you could use the more familiar term in your area, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [foul language] or [unwholesome words] or [abusive speech]
The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. Speaking what is corrupt is in contrast to speaking good things that will build up others.
Alternate translation: [for encouraging] or [for strengthening]
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of speaking things that build up others is to give grace to those who hear the words.

notes.orig_language_quote: τῆς χρείας, ἵνα δῷ χάριν τοῖς ἀκούουσιν
notes.note: Alternate translation: [the needy. In this way you will help those who hear you]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **grace**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [so that those who hear you may be spiritually encouraged]

bsb_verse_text: And do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, in whom you were sealed for the day of redemption.
ult_verse_text: and do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, by whom you were sealed for the day of redemption.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [do not distress] or [do not upset]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐν ᾧ ἐσφραγίσθητε εἰς ἡμέραν ἀπολυτρώσεως
notes.note: The Holy Spirit assures believers that God will redeem them. Paul speaks of the Holy Spirit as if he were a mark that God puts on believers to show that he owns them. Alternate translation: [for he is the seal that assures you that God will redeem you on the day of redemption] or [for he is the one who assures you that God will redeem you on the day of redemption]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐν ᾧ ἐσφραγίσθητε εἰς ἡμέραν ἀπολυτρώσεως
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [for he has sealed you for the day of redemption]

bsb_verse_text: Get rid of all bitterness, rage and anger, outcry and slander, along with every form of malice.
ult_verse_text: Let all bitterness, and rage, and anger, and quarreling, and insults be removed from yourselves, along with all malice.

notes.note: Paul finishes his instructions on what believers should not do and ends with what they must do. Paul speaks of attitudes and behaviors as though they were physical objects that can be removed. Alternate translation: [you must not allow … to be part of your life]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the words **bitterness**, **rage**, and **anger**, you could express the same ideas as adjectives. Alternate translation: [being bitter, and intensely angry, and angry]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **malice**, you could express the same idea as an adjective. Alternate translation: [being malicious]

bsb_verse_text: Be kind and tenderhearted to one another, forgiving each other just as in Christ God forgave you.
ult_verse_text: Instead, be kind to each other, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, just as God in Christ also forgave you.

notes.note: The connecting word **Instead** introduces a contrast relationship. Speaking angry and hurtful things is in contrast to speaking kind and tender things to one another.
Alternate translation: [gentle and compassionate towards others]

bsb_verse_text: Be imitators of God, therefore, as beloved children,
ult_verse_text: Therefore, be imitators of God, as beloved children,

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **imitators**, you could express the same idea in another way.The word **imitators** is a verbal noun, and can be translated with a verb. Alternate translation: [Therefore, imitate God] or [Therefore you should do what God does.]

The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. Paul continues to tell the believers how they should and should not live as God’s children. The reason (stated in [Ephesians 4:32](../04/32.md)) is that God has forgiven us through Christ. The result (stated here) is that believers should imitate what God is like. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

God desires us to imitate or follow him since we are his spiritual **children**. Alternate translation: [as dearly loved children imitate their fathers] or [because you are his children and he loves you dearly]

bsb_verse_text: and walk in love, just as Christ loved us and gave Himself up for us as a fragrant sacrificial offering to God.
ult_verse_text: and walk in love, as also Christ loved us and gave himself up for us, an offering and sacrifice to God for a fragrant aroma.

notes.note: To **walk** is a common way to express the idea of living one’s life. Alternate translation: [live a life of love] or [always love each other]

notes.orig_language_quote: προσφορὰν καὶ θυσίαν τῷ Θεῷ εἰς ὀσμὴν εὐωδίας
notes.note: This metaphor compares Christ dying on the cross for our sins with an Old Testament **sacrifice** for sin, which were roasted in a fire and gave off a pleasing smell. Alternate translation: [like a sweet-smelling offering and sacrifice to God] or [an offering and sacrifice to God that pleased God very much]

bsb_verse_text: But among you, as is proper among the saints, there must not be even a hint of sexual immorality, or of any kind of impurity, or of greed.
ult_verse_text: But sexual immorality and every impurity or greed must not even be named among you, just as is proper for saints,

notes.orig_language_quote: πορνεία δὲ, καὶ ἀκαθαρσία πᾶσα, ἢ πλεονεξία, μηδὲ ὀνομαζέσθω ἐν ὑμῖν
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [Do not do anything that would let anyone think that you are guilty of sexual immorality or any kind of impurity or greed]

The connecting word **But** introduces a contrast relationship. The fragrant offering and sacrifice to God is in contrast to sinful acts and thoughts that are not fitting for saints. Use a connecting word that indicates a contrast in your language.
Alternate translation: [any moral uncleanness]

bsb_verse_text: Nor should there be obscenity, foolish talk, or crude joking, which are out of character, but rather thanksgiving.
ult_verse_text: and filthiness and foolish talk or crude jokes—which are not fitting—but instead, thanksgiving.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **thanksgiving**, you could express the same idea in another way. The word **thanksgiving** is a verbal noun, and can be translated with a verb. Alternate translation: [instead of those things, you should thank God]

The connecting phrase **but instead** introduces a contrast relationship. Sinful acts and thoughts are in contrast to thanksgiving to God. Use a connecting word that indicates a contrast in your language.

bsb_verse_text: For of this you can be sure: No immoral, impure, or greedy person (that is, an idolater) has any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.
ult_verse_text: Indeed, know this for certain, that every sexually immoral or unclean or greedy {person}—that is, an idolater—has no inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.

notes.note: Being **unclean** (dirty) is a metaphor for being sinful.
Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. Alternate translation: [will receive nothing] or [has no part]

bsb_verse_text: Let no one deceive you with empty words, for because of such things the wrath of God is coming on the sons of disobedience.
ult_verse_text: Let no one deceive you with empty words, for because of these things the wrath of God is coming upon the sons of disobedience.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [with words that have no truth in them] or [by speaking words that are not true]

The connecting word **for** introduces a reason-result relationship. The result is stated first: that the Ephesian believers should not let anyone deceive them with empty words. Then the reason is stated: that the wrath of God will judge those things. Use a phrase that connects a reason to a result, and put them in the order that is most natural in your language.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἔρχεται ἡ ὀργὴ τοῦ Θεοῦ ἐπὶ
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **wrath**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [God will certainly punish]
This is an idiom that means, “people who habitually disobey” or “people who are characterized by disobedience” Alternate translation: [those who disobey God]

bsb_verse_text: Therefore do not be partakers with them.
ult_verse_text: Therefore, do not become partners with them,

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that God will judge those people in his wrath. The result is that the Ephesian believers should not become partners with evil men. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

bsb_verse_text: For you were once darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of light,
ult_verse_text: because formerly you were darkness, but now {are} light in the Lord. Walk as children of light

notes.note: Just as one cannot see in the dark, so people who love to sin cannot see or understand the things of God. Alternate translation: [because formerly you did not understand anything about God]

The connecting word **because** introduces a reason-result relationship. The result is stated first (v.7): that the Ephesian believers should not become partners with evil men. The reason is stated second (v. 8): that the Ephesian believers are no longer darkness, but are now light. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result, using the order that is most natural for your language.
Just as one can see in the **light**, so people whom God has saved understand how to please God. Alternate translation: [but now you know God and can live for him]
The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. The fact that the Ephesian believers were formerly darkness is in contrast to the fact that they are now light.
To **Walk** on a path is a metaphor for how a person lives his life. Alternate translation: [Live as people who understand what the Lord wants them to do]
God desires us to imitate or follow him since we are his spiritual **children**. Alternate translation: [as God’s children who know the truth] or [because you are God’s children and see the truth]

bsb_verse_text: for the fruit of the light consists in all goodness, righteousness, and truth.
ult_verse_text: (for the fruit of the light consists in all goodness and righteousness and truth),

notes.orig_language_quote: ὁ & καρπὸς τοῦ φωτὸς ἐν πάσῃ ἀγαθωσύνῃ, καὶ δικαιοσύνῃ, καὶ ἀληθείᾳ
notes.note: Here, **fruit** is a metaphor for “result” or “outcome.” Alternate translation: [the result of living in the light is good work, right living, and truthful behavior]

The connecting word **for** introduces the reason of a reason-result relationship. The reason is that fruit of the light is goodness and righteousness and truth. The result is that the Ephesian believers should walk as children of light. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

bsb_verse_text: Have no fellowship with the fruitless deeds of darkness, but rather expose them.
ult_verse_text: And do not take part in the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather even expose {them}.

notes.orig_language_quote: μὴ συνκοινωνεῖτε τοῖς ἔργοις τοῖς ἀκάρποις τοῦ σκότους
notes.note: Paul speaks of the useless, sinful things that unbelievers do as if they are evil deeds that people do in the dark so no one will see them. Alternate translation: [do not do useless, sinful things with unbelievers]

notes.orig_language_quote: τοῖς ἔργοις τοῖς ἀκάρποις τοῦ σκότους
notes.note: Paul is comparing evil actions to an unhealthy tree that produces nothing good. Alternate translation: [actions that do nothing good, useful, or profitable, caused by darkness]

notes.orig_language_quote: τοῖς ἔργοις τοῖς ἀκάρποις τοῦ σκότους
notes.note: The word **darkness** is often used to represent sin. In this instance, these works result from sinful motives. Alternate translation: [deeds that are worthless because they were done from sinful motives]
The connecting phrase **but rather** introduces contrast relationship. Participating in the works of darkness is in contrast to exposing them.

Speaking against the works of darkness is spoken of as bringing them out into the light so that people can see them. Alternate translation: [bring them out into the light] or [uncover them] or [show and tell people how wrong these actions are]

bsb_verse_text: For it is shameful even to mention what the disobedient do in secret.
ult_verse_text: For it is shameful even to mention the things done by them in secret.

notes.note: Here, **them** refers to the “sons of disobedience” mentioned in [5:6](../05/06.md) and also referred to as “them” in [5:7](../05/07.md). If it is unclear who “them” refers to in either place, then use “those who disobey God” or a similar phrase.

bsb_verse_text: But everything exposed by the light becomes visible, for everything that is illuminated becomes a light itself.
ult_verse_text: But everything exposed by the light is revealed, for everything that is revealed is light.

notes.note: The connecting word **But** introduces a contrast relationship. Hiding the shameful works of darkness now is in contrast to the light exposing them later.

Paul makes this general statement in order to imply that God’s Word shows people’s actions to be good or bad. The Bible often speaks of God’s truth as if it were **light** that could reveal the character of something. Alternate translation: [if you compare everything to what God says, you could know if it is good or bad]

bsb_verse_text: So it is said: “Wake up, O sleeper, rise up from the dead, and Christ will shine on you.”
ult_verse_text: Therefore it says,

notes.note: The connecting word **Therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that their sins will be revealed by the light. The result is that sinners should allow Christ to shine on them. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result. It is unknown if this quotation is a combination of quotations from the prophet Isaiah or a quotation from a hymn sung by the believers.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἔγειρε, ὁ καθεύδων, καὶ ἀνάστα ἐκ τῶν νεκρῶν
notes.note: This could mean: (1) Paul is addressing the believers and using death as a metaphor for the areas of spiritual weakness that they need to become aware of and reject. (2) Paul is addressing unbelievers who need to wake up from being dead spiritually, just as a person who has died must come alive again in order to respond.

This could mean: (1 )Paul is addressing this comment directly to unbelievers who are not reading or hearing the letter. (2) Paul is addressing this comment directly to the believers who are reading or hearing the letter.

This expression describes all **dead** people together in the underworld. To arise from among them speaks of becoming alive again and is a metaphor for becoming alive spiritually and living for God. Alternate translation: [from among all those who have died] or [from among those who are spiritually dead]
Here, **you** refers to the “sleeper” and is singular.

**Christ** will enable an unbeliever to understand how evil his deeds are and how Christ will forgive him and give him new life, just as light shows what actually is there that the darkness had hidden. This also applies to anything that a believer has not yet recognized as sinful. Alternate translation: [Christ will show you what is right]

bsb_verse_text: Pay careful attention, then, to how you walk, not as unwise but as wise,
ult_verse_text: Watch carefully, therefore, how you walk—not as unwise but as wise,

notes.orig_language_quote: βλέπετε οὖν ἀκριβῶς πῶς περιπατεῖτε, μὴ ὡς ἄσοφοι, ἀλλ’ ὡς σοφοί
notes.note: Paul assumes that his readers will understand that people who are **unwise** do not guard themselves against sin. Wise people, however, can identify sin and flee from it. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [Therefore, you must be careful to live as a wise person rather than a foolish person]

The connecting word **therefore** introduces a reason-result relationship. The reason is that Christ has shown the light on him. The result is that the sinner will walk carefully in the light. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. Being unwise is in contrast to being wise.

notes.orig_language_quote: μὴ ὡς ἄσοφοι, ἀλλ’ ὡς σοφοί
notes.note: The verb “walk” is left out. You can state this clearly. Alternate translation: [not walking as those who are unwise but walking as those who are wise]

notes.orig_language_quote: μὴ ὡς ἄσοφοι, ἀλλ’ ὡς σοφοί,
notes.note: Paul is using the adjectives **unwise** and **wise** as nouns to mean certain kinds of people. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with equivalent phrases. Alternate translation: [not as those who act unwisely but as those who act wisely]

bsb_verse_text: redeeming the time, because the days are evil.
ult_verse_text: redeeming the time because the days are evil.

notes.note: Using time wisely is spoken of as if it were **redeeming the time**. Alternate translation: [doing the best things you can with your time] or [using time wisely] or [putting time to its best use]

The word **days** is a metonym for what people do during those days. Alternate translation: [because the people around you are constantly doing all kinds of evil things and the opportunities that you have to do good may become few]

The connecting word **because** introduces the reason of a reason-result relationship. The reason is that the days are evil. The result is that the believers must redeem the time. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

bsb_verse_text: Therefore do not be foolish, but understand what the Lord’s will is.
ult_verse_text: Because of this, do not be foolish, but understand what the will of the Lord {is}.

notes.note: The connecting phrase **Because of this** introduces the result of a reason-result relationship. The reason is that the days are evil. The result is that the believers will not be foolish, but understand God’s will. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. Being foolish is in contrast to understanding God’s will.

bsb_verse_text: Do not get drunk on wine, which leads to reckless indiscretion. Instead, be filled with the Spirit.
ult_verse_text: And do not get drunk with wine, in which is recklessness. Instead, be filled with the Spirit,

notes.note: Paul ends his instructions on how all believers should live. Alternate translation: [You should not get drunk from drinking wine]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **recklessness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [which leads to reckless behavior] or [because that will ruin you]
Alternate translation: [Instead, you should be controlled by the Holy Spirit]
The connecting word **Instead** introduces a contrast relationship. Being drunk is in contrast to being filled with the Spirit.

bsb_verse_text: Speak to one another with psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs. Sing and make music in your hearts to the Lord,
ult_verse_text: speaking to each other in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and singing psalms in your heart to the Lord,

notes.orig_language_quote: ψαλμοῖς, καὶ ὕμνοις, καὶ ᾠδαῖς πνευματικαῖς
notes.note: This could mean: (1) Paul is using these words as a merism for “all sorts of songs to praise God” (2) Paul is listing specific forms of music.

Paul assumes that his readers will understand that these **psalms** are probably songs from the Old Testament book of Psalms that believers sang in worship. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the lyrical poems of David and others]
These **hymns** are songs of praise and worship that may have been written specifically for Christians to sing.

This could mean: (1) these are songs that the Holy Spirit inspires a person to sing right at that moment (2) **spiritual songs** and “hymns” form a doublet. They mean basically the same thing, and you could use one word for these instead of two.

Here, **heart** is a metonym for a person’s thoughts or inner being. This could mean: (1) they should do this with true motives and sincerity. Alternate translation: [from deep within your being] or [sincerely]; (2) they should do this with enthusiasm: Alternate translation: [with all of your being] or [enthusiastically]

bsb_verse_text: always giving thanks to God the Father for everything in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
ult_verse_text: giving thanks always for everything in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ to God, even the Father,

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐν ὀνόματι τοῦ Κυρίου ἡμῶν, Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
notes.note: Here, **name** could refer to: (1) Jesus himself. Alternate translation: [because you belong to our Lord Jesus Christ]; (2) the authority of Jesus. Alternate translation: [with the authority of our Lord Jesus Christ]
Alternate translation: [to God, who is our Father]

bsb_verse_text: Submit to one another out of reverence for Christ.
ult_verse_text: submitting yourselves to one another in reverence for Christ—

notes.note: Paul assumes that his readers will understand that he is continuing to explain what it means to “be filled with the Spirit” ([Ephesians 5:18](../05/18.md)). You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Here Paul says that Christians are to submit themselves to one another. Alternate translation: [yielding to fellow believers]

notes.orig_language_quote: αἱ γυναῖκες τοῖς ἰδίοις ἀνδράσιν ὡς τῷ Κυρίῳ,
notes.note: Paul is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words from earlier in the sentence if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [wives, submitting yourselves to your own husbands, just as you submit yourselves to the Lord]

bsb_verse_text: For the husband is the head of the wife as Christ is the head of the church, His body, of which He is the Savior.
ult_verse_text: For a husband is the head of the wife as Christ also {is} the head of the church—he himself {is} the savior of the body.

notes.note: The connecting word **For** introduces the reason of the reason-result relationship. The reason is that the husband is head of the wife in the same way that Christ is head of the church. The result is that wives should submit to their husbands. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

notes.orig_language_quote: κεφαλὴ τῆς γυναικὸς & κεφαλὴ τῆς ἐκκλησίας
notes.note: The word **head** here represents the leader.
The church is often referred to as the **body** of Christ.

bsb_verse_text: Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave Himself up for her
ult_verse_text: Husbands, love your wives just as Christ also loved the church and gave himself up for her,

notes.note: Here the words **himself** and **he** refer to Christ. The word **her** refers to the church.

Here, the command to **love** implies that the husband unselfishly does what is best for the wife, unselfishly serving or giving to his wife, following the example of Christ. Alternate translation: [sacrifice yourselves for your wives]
Alternate translation: [allowed people to kill him]
Paul speaks of the assembly of believers as though she were a woman whom Jesus will marry. Alternate translation: [for us]

bsb_verse_text: to sanctify her, cleansing her by the washing with water through the word,
ult_verse_text: so that he might sanctify her, having cleansed her by the washing of the water with the word,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of Christ giving himself up to death is to sanctify the church.
Paul speaks of the assembly of believers as though she were a woman whom Jesus will marry. Alternate translation: [he might make us holy, having cleansed us]

notes.orig_language_quote: καθαρίσας τῷ λουτρῷ τοῦ ὕδατος ἐν ῥήματι
notes.note: This could mean: (1) Paul is referring to God making Christ’s people clean by the preaching and acceptance of God’s **word** in the gospel message and through **water** baptism in Christ. (2) Paul is speaking of God making us spiritually clean from our sins by the message as if God were making our bodies clean by washing them with **water**.

bsb_verse_text: and to present her to Himself as a glorious church, without stain or wrinkle or any such blemish, but holy and blameless.
ult_verse_text: so that he might present the church to himself as glorious, not having stain or wrinkle or any of those things, but so that she might be holy and blameless.

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of Christ cleansing the church with the word is to present the church to himself as a glorious bride.
Paul speaks of the church as though it were a garment that is clean and in perfect condition. Alternate translation: [not having any defect]

Here, **stain** and **wrinkle** represent the same idea of defect in two ways to emphasize the church’s purity. If your language does not have two different words, you can use one word for this. Alternate translation: [not having damage]
The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. The church having stains and wrinkles of sin is in contrast to the church being holy and blameless.
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of Christ washing the church is to make the church holy and blameless.

Here, **blameless** means basically the same thing as **holy**. Paul uses the two together to emphasize the church’s purity. If your language does not have two different words, you can use one word for this.

bsb_verse_text: In the same way, husbands ought to love their wives as their own bodies. He who loves his wife loves himself.
ult_verse_text: In the same way, the husbands also ought to love their own wives as their own bodies. The one loving his own wife loves himself.

notes.note: You can state explicitly that people love **their own bodies**. Alternate translation: [as husbands love their own bodies]

bsb_verse_text: Indeed, no one ever hated his own body, but he nourishes and cherishes it, just as Christ does the church.
ult_verse_text: For no one ever hated his own body, but he nourishes and treats it with care, just as Christ also {does} the church,

notes.note: Alternate translation: [but he feeds]
The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. Hating one’s own body is in contrast to caring for it.

bsb_verse_text: For we are members of His body.
ult_verse_text: because we are members of his body.

notes.note: The connecting word **because** introduces the reason of a reason-result relationship. The reason is that the church is Christ’s body. The result is that Christ cares for the church. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result. Alternate translation: [since]
Paul speaks of the close union of believers with Christ as if they were part of his own **body**, for which he would naturally care.

bsb_verse_text: “For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one flesh.”
ult_verse_text: “Because of this a man will leave his father and his mother and will be joined to his wife, and the two will become one flesh.”

notes.note: The quotation is from the writings of Moses in the Old Testament. The word **his** refers to a male believer who marries.

The connecting phrase **Because of this** introduces the result of a reason-result relationship. In this case, this phrase is part of a quotation from [Genesis 2:24](../../gen/02/24.md), and so the reason is not stated here, but it is stated in [Genesis 2:23](../../gen/02/23.md) that woman was created out of man. The result is that a man will leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife. If it is confusing to not state the reason, you could include a footnote that says, “the reason for this is that woman was created out of man. See [Genesis 2:23](../../gen/02/23.md)”

bsb_verse_text: Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is right.
ult_verse_text: Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is righteous.

notes.note: The command in verse one is plural. Then in verses two and three Paul quotes from the law of Moses. Moses was talking to the people of Israel as though they were one person, so **your** and **you** are singular there. If that does not make sense, you may need to translate them as plurals.

Paul continues to explain how Christians, people who live **in the Lord**, are to submit themselves to each other. He gives instructions to children, fathers, workers, and masters. Alternate translation: [because you belong to the Lord] or [as followers of the Lord]

The connecting word **for** introduces the reason of a reason-result relationship. The reason is that children should do what is right. The result is that children should obey their parents. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

bsb_verse_text: “that it may go well with you and that you may have a long life on the earth.”
ult_verse_text: “so that it may be well with you and you may be long-lived on the earth.”

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of obeying your father and mother is to live well and long on the earth.

bsb_verse_text: Fathers, do not provoke your children to wrath; instead, bring them up in the discipline and instruction of the Lord.
ult_verse_text: And fathers, do not provoke your children to anger. Instead, raise them in the discipline and instruction of the Lord.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [do not make your children angry] or [do not cause your children to be angry]
The connecting word **Instead** introduces a contrast relationship. Fathers provoking their children to anger is in contrast to raising their children in discipline and instruction.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐκτρέφετε αὐτὰ ἐν παιδείᾳ καὶ νουθεσίᾳ Κυρίου
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the words **discipline** and **instruction**, you could express the same ideas with verbal forms. Alternate translation: [teach them to become adults by making sure that they know and do what the Lord wants them to do]

bsb_verse_text: Slaves, obey your earthly masters with respect and fear and sincerity of heart, just as you would obey Christ.
ult_verse_text: Slaves, obey your masters according to the flesh with fear and trembling, in honesty of your heart, as to Christ,

notes.note: The phrase **fear and trembling** uses two similar ideas to emphasize the importance of honoring their masters. Alternate translation: [with deep respect]
Here, **trembling** is an exaggeration used to emphasize how important it is that slaves obey their masters. Alternate translation: [and deep respect] or [as though you were shaking with fear]
Here, **heart** is a metonym for a person’s mind or intentions. Alternate translation: [with honesty] or [with sincerity]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **honesty**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [honestly] or [sincerely]
To make the meaning of this phrase clear, you may want to include the verb here: “as you obey Christ.”

bsb_verse_text: And do this not only to please them while they are watching, but as servants of Christ, doing the will of God from your heart.
ult_verse_text: not with eye-service as men-pleasers, but as slaves of Christ, doing the will of God from the soul,

notes.note: The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. Obeying our masters as men-pleasers is in contrast to obeying them because we are slaves of Christ.
Alternate translation: [as though your earthly master were Christ himself]
Here, **soul** is a metonym for “attitudes” or “intentions.” Alternate translation: [wholeheartedly] or [enthusiastically]

bsb_verse_text: And masters, do the same for your slaves. Give up your use of threats, because you know that He who is both their Master and yours is in heaven, and there is no favoritism with Him.
ult_verse_text: And masters, do the same to them. Stop using threats. You know that the Master, both theirs and yours, is in heaven, and there is no favoritism with him.

notes.note: Here, **the same** refers back to “if he does something good” from ([Ephesians 6:8](../06/08.md)). Alternate translation: [you also must treat your slaves well] or [just as slaves must do good to their masters, you also must do good to your slaves]

notes.orig_language_quote: εἰδότες ὅτι καὶ αὐτῶν καὶ ὑμῶν ὁ Κύριός ἐστιν ἐν οὐρανοῖς
notes.note: Alternate translation: [You know that Christ is the Master of both slaves and their masters, and that he is in heaven]
Alternate translation: [he judges everyone the same way]

bsb_verse_text: Finally, be strong in the Lord and in His mighty power.
ult_verse_text: Finally, be strong in the Lord and in the force of his strength.

notes.note: Paul is using the word translated **Finally** to introduce a new event in the story. Here Paul gives instructions to make believers strong in this battle we are in for God. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event. Alternate translation: [In conclusion]

These two words, **force** and **strength**, are very similar in meaning. Together, they reinforce each other. See how you translated this phrase near the end of [Ephesians 1:19](../01/19.md) Alternate translation: [his great power]

bsb_verse_text: Put on the full armor of God, so that you can make your stand against the devil’s schemes.
ult_verse_text: Put on the whole armor of God, to enable you to stand against the scheming of the devil.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐνδύσασθε τὴν πανοπλίαν τοῦ Θεοῦ, πρὸς τὸ δύνασθαι ὑμᾶς στῆναι πρὸς τὰς μεθοδίας τοῦ διαβόλου
notes.note: In this metaphor, Paul pictures the spiritual resources that **God** gives to all Christians as a soldier’s **armor**. Alternate translation: [Just as a soldier puts on armor to protect himself from enemy attacks, use all of God’s resources to stand firmly against the devil]
Alternate translation: [the tricky plans]

bsb_verse_text: For our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the powers of this world’s darkness, and against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms.
ult_verse_text: For our struggle is not against blood and flesh, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the world-controllers of this darkness, against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly {places}.

notes.note: The connecting word **For** introduces the reason of this reason-result relationship. The reason is that we are in a struggle against spiritual forces of darkness. The result is that we should put on the whole armor of God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.
This expression refers to people, not to spirits who do not have human bodies. Alternate translation: [human beings]
The connecting word **but** introduces a contrast relationship. People made of flesh and blood are in contrast to spiritual forces.

Here it is implied that **the world-controllers** refers to powerful spiritual beings. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [against the powerful spiritual beings that rule over people]
Here, **darkness** is a metaphor for things that are evil. Alternate translation: [during this present evil time]

bsb_verse_text: Therefore take up the full armor of God, so that when the day of evil comes, you will be able to stand your ground, and having done everything, to stand.
ult_verse_text: Because of this, put on the whole armor of God, so that you may be able to withstand in the evil day, and, having done everything, to stand.

notes.orig_language_quote: διὰ τοῦτο, ἀναλάβετε τὴν πανοπλίαν τοῦ Θεοῦ
notes.note: Christians should use the protective resources **God** gives them in fighting the devil in the same way that a soldier puts on **armor** to protect himself against his enemies.

The connecting phrase **Because of this** introduces the result of a reason-result relationship. The reason is that we are in a battle against evil spiritual forces. The result is that we should put on the whole armor of God. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἵνα δυνηθῆτε ἀντιστῆναι ἐν τῇ ἡμέρᾳ τῇ πονηρᾷ
notes.note: The word **withstand** means to successfully resist something. Alternate translation: [so that you may be able to resist when evil attacks you]
It may be helpful to state explicitly what believers are to **withstand**. Alternate translation: [so that you may be able to withstand the attacks of the devil]
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of putting on the whole armor of God is to be able to withstand the attacks of the spiritual forces of darkness.

bsb_verse_text: Stand firm then, with the belt of truth buckled around your waist, with the breastplate of righteousness arrayed,
ult_verse_text: Stand, therefore, having girded up your loins with truth and having put on the breastplate of righteousness,

notes.note: The word **Stand** represents taking a position on what is right and true and successfully resisting forces that try to make the believer compromise that position. See how you translated “stand firm” in [Ephesians 6:13](../06/13.md). Alternate translation: [So resist evil]

The connecting word **therefore** introduces the result of a reason-result relationship. The reason is that we believers have put on our spiritual armor. The result is that we will stand and resist the evil spiritual forces. Use a phrase in your language that connects a reason to a result.

notes.orig_language_quote: περιζωσάμενοι τὴν ὀσφὺν ὑμῶν ἐν ἀληθείᾳ
notes.note: In this metaphor, **truth** is compared to a soldier’s belt. Truth holds everything together for a believer just as a belt holds the clothing of a soldier together. Alternate translation: [having wrapped yourself in all that is true]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **truth**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [what is true]

In this metaphor, **righteousness** is compared to a soldier’s **breastplate**. Just as soldiers put on a breastplate to protect themselves from enemy attacks, believers should behave in a righteous way to protect themselves from spiritual attacks.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **righteousness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [the right way to live]

bsb_verse_text: and with your feet fitted with the readiness of the gospel of peace.
ult_verse_text: and having shod your feet with readiness of the gospel of peace.

notes.orig_language_quote: ὑποδησάμενοι τοὺς πόδας ἐν ἑτοιμασίᾳ τοῦ εὐαγγελίου τῆς εἰρήνης
notes.note: In this metaphor, **the gospel of peace** is compared to a soldier’s sandals. Just as a soldier wears sturdy footwear to give him solid footing and enable him to march long distances, the believer must have solid knowledge of the gospel of peace and be ready to go where the Lord sends him to proclaim it.

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **peace**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [that makes everything good between people and God]

bsb_verse_text: In addition to all this, take up the shield of faith, with which you can extinguish all the flaming arrows of the evil one.
ult_verse_text: In everything take up the shield of the faith, by which you will be able to extinguish all the flaming arrows of the evil one.

notes.orig_language_quote: ἐν πᾶσιν ἀναλαβόντες τὸν θυρεὸν τῆς πίστεως
notes.note: In this metaphor, faith is compared to a soldier’s **shield**. Just as a soldier uses a shield to protect himself from enemy attacks, the believer must use the **faith** that God gives for protection when the devil attacks.

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faith**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [that represents how much you trust in the Lord]
The attacks of the devil against a believer are like **flaming arrows** shot at a soldier by an enemy.

bsb_verse_text: And take the helmet of salvation and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God.
ult_verse_text: And take the helmet of salvation and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God.

notes.note: The **salvation** that God gives protects the believer’s mind just as a **helmet** protects the head of a soldier.

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [that represents the fact that God has saved you]

notes.orig_language_quote: τὴν μάχαιραν τοῦ Πνεύματος, ὅ ἐστιν ῥῆμα Θεοῦ
notes.note: In this metaphor, God’s message is compared to a soldier’s **sword**. Just as soldiers use a sword to fight and defeat their enemy, so a believer can use God’s message in the Bible to fight against the devil.

bsb_verse_text: Pray in the Spirit at all times, with every kind of prayer and petition. To this end, stay alert with all perseverance in your prayers for all the saints.
ult_verse_text: With every prayer and request, pray at all times in the Spirit. And to this {end}, be watchful with all perseverance and requests for all the saints,

notes.orig_language_quote: διὰ πάσης προσευχῆς καὶ δεήσεως, προσευχόμενοι ἐν παντὶ καιρῷ ἐν Πνεύματι
notes.note: Alternate translation: [Pray at all times in the Spirit as you pray and make specific requests]

The connecting phrase **to this {end}** marks a goal or purpose relationship. The goal is what was just mentioned: to pray at all times in the Spirit. In order to do that, believers must be watchful and persevere in making requests for all the saints. Alternate translation: [for this reason] or [in order to do that]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἀγρυπνοῦντες ἐν πάσῃ προσκαρτερήσει καὶ δεήσει περὶ πάντων τῶν ἁγίων
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **perseverance**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [persevere in being alert, and pray for all God’s holy people] or [pray with constant alertness for all the believers]

bsb_verse_text: Pray also for me, that whenever I open my mouth, words may be given me so that I will boldly make known the mystery of the gospel,
ult_verse_text: and for me, so that a message might be given to me in the opening of my mouth, to make known with boldness the mystery of the gospel

notes.note: Paul is leaving out a word that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words from earlier in the sentence if it would be clearer in your language. In closing this letter, Paul asks his readers to pray for his boldness in telling the gospel. Alternate translation: [and pray for me]
If your language does not use this passive form, you can state this in active form. Alternate translation: [that God might give me the word] or [God might give me the message]
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of the believers praying for Paul is to enable him to preach the gospel boldly.
This is a metonym for speaking. Alternate translation: [my speaking] or [in what I say]

bsb_verse_text: for which I am an ambassador in chains. Pray that I may proclaim it fearlessly, as I should.
ult_verse_text: (for which I am an ambassador in chains), so that in it I may speak boldly, as it is necessary for me to speak.

notes.note: The phrase **in chains** is a metonym for being in prison. Alternate translation: [because of which I am now in prison]

notes.orig_language_quote: ἵνα ἐν αὐτῷ παρρησιάσωμαι, ὡς δεῖ με λαλῆσαι
notes.note: The word “pray” is understood from [verse 18](../06/18.md). Alternate translation: [pray that whenever I teach the gospel, I will speak it as boldly as I should] or [pray that I may speak the gospel as boldly as I should]
The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of the believers praying for Paul is to enable him to preach the gospel boldly even though he is in chains.

Here, **it** refers back to the “message” in [verse 19](../06/19.md) that Paul wants to speak. If it would be helpful in your language, you could repeat the word “message” here. Alternate translation: [in my message]

bsb_verse_text: Tychicus, the beloved brother and faithful servant in the Lord, will tell you everything, so that you also may know about me and what I am doing.
ult_verse_text: But so that you also may know the things concerning me, how I am doing, Tychicus, the beloved brother and faithful servant in the Lord, will make known to you everything,

notes.note: The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of Paul sending Tychicus to Ephesus was to tell the Ephesian believers what was happening to Paul.
Paul speaks of Tychicus as if he were a **brother** to all the other believers who were in God’s spiritual family. Alternate translation: [fellow believer]

bsb_verse_text: I have sent him to you for this very purpose, that you may know about us, and that he may encourage your hearts.
ult_verse_text: whom I have sent to you for this very purpose, so that you may know the things about us and your hearts may be encouraged.

notes.note: Here, **hearts** is a metonym for people’s inner beings. Alternate translation: [he may encourage you]

The connecting phrase **so that** introduces a goal relationship. The goal or purpose of Paul sending Tychicus to the Ephesians is to encourage their hearts and to let them know what was happening to Paul and his companions.

bsb_verse_text: Peace to the brothers and love with faith from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
ult_verse_text: Peace to the brothers, and love with faith from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

notes.orig_language_quote: εἰρήνη τοῖς ἀδελφοῖς καὶ ἀγάπη μετὰ πίστεως ἀπὸ Θεοῦ Πατρὸς καὶ Κυρίου Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ.
notes.note: Paul closes his letter to the Ephesian believers with a blessing of **Peace** and **love** on all believers who love Christ. You could express this as either a blessing or a prayer, in whichever way is more natural in your language.

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **Peace**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [May the brothers have a peaceful spirit]
Paul speaks of the other believers as if they were **brothers** to all of the other believers who were in God’s spiritual family. Alternate translation: [to the fellow believers]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **love**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [may you love one another]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faith**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [as you trust in the Lord]

bsb_verse_text: Grace to all who love our Lord Jesus Christ with an undying love.
ult_verse_text: Grace {be} with all the ones loving our Lord Jesus Christ with incorruptibility.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **Grace**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [May God act graciously to]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **incorruptibility**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: [in a way that no one is able to corrupt] or [so much that no one can make them stop loving him]
